awd_titl_txt: NNCI:The Kentucky Multi-scale Manufacturing and Nano Integration Node (MMNIN)
awd_abstract_narration:
The National Nanotechnology Coordinated Infrastructure (NNCI) Kentucky Multi-scale Manufacturing and Nano Integration Node (MMNIN) is a collaboration between the University of Louisville and the University of Kentucky focused on integrating manufacturing technology over widely different length scales. With nanotechnology now integral to scientific discovery and engineering, there is a pressing need for infrastructure that supports the rapid and effective prototyping of nano-scale devices in macro-scale systems. The goal of the MMNIN is to combine micro/nano fabrication processes with the latest in 3D additive manufacturing technology to allow researchers to explore nanotechnology solutions to real-life problems in healthcare, energy, the environment, communication, and security. In addition to having access to state-of-the-art tools and expertise, MMNIN participants will conduct novel research addressing multi-scale manufacturing and integration challenges with a particular focus on the interfaces between different length scales, materials and manufacturing processes.  The MMNIN's state-of-the-art multidisciplinary infrastructure will serve a growing user base whose home institutions include high schools, university laboratories, government facilities, startup ventures, and Fortune 100 companies.  Through new educational and seed research programs, MMNIN will offer unique opportunities to users from traditionally underrepresented regions and groups, including the Appalachian region of the United States. The MMNIN's unique focus and central location (60% of the US population within a day's drive) will greatly encourage external usage. Through these efforts MMNIN seeks to transform the interfaces between the nano-scale and the human scale and impact society by rapidly providing new multi-scale technological solutions. 

The MMNIN will be the first open user facility nationwide with a focus on 3D micro/nano fabrication and true multi-scale integration.  Users will have access to design, simulation, and fabrication resources that span the nanometer to meter scales, and the expertise to effectively integrate these processes. At the nano-scale, MMNIN will provide rapid prototyping capabilities based on election- and ion-beam induced processes and two-photon polymerization along with the expertise to convert the prototyped structures to functional devices. At the micro-scale, users will have access to a variety of unique fabrication processes including stress engineered thin-film deposition for self-programmed 2D to 3D fabrication, 128 level grayscale lithography for rapid prototyping of complex 3D structures, micro aerosol jet 3D printing using conductive, resistive, dielectric and biological materials, as well as a diversity of traditional semiconductor and MEMS fabrication processes using MMNIN's new class 100  $30M, 10,000 sq. ft. cleanroom facility.  At the meso/macro-scale, MMNIN offers automated roll-to-roll manufacturing processes and the latest in additive manufacturing tools for 3D printing custom structures and enclosures using metals and/or polymers. MMNIN also offers a variety of characterization techniques ranging from transmission electron microscopy to squid magnetometry. All of these efforts involve exciting research challenges, not only on the processes themselves, but also on the integration of these processes to make reliable electrical, mechanical, optical, and fluidic interfaces between the length scales. As a result, users will be able to create systems such as nano-scale sensors in biocompatible enclosures, artificial crystalline optical filters with high density interconnects, and nano-electronics that expand from the substrate to interact with the external world.  Ultimately, these capabilities, combined with the MMNIN faculty expertise in multi-scale manufacturing and integration, will allow users to rapidly and economically produce products and solutions addressing society's pressing challenges.

por.por_cntn:
This 5-year award provided critical funding for the creation of the successful Kentucky Multi-scale Manufacturing and Nano Integration Node (or simply "KY Multiscale" for short), which is part of the National Science Foundation's prestigious National Nanotechnology Coordinated Infrastructure (NNCI).  The NNCI is a 16-site geographically distributed network of university state-of-the-art core facilities available to all users throughout the United States for the fabrication and characterization of next generation nano-materials, micro-devices, and complex systems (see Figure 1). KY Multiscale, a site in the NNCI national network, is a collaboration between the University of Louisville and the University of Kentucky focused on the convergence of nanotechnology with next-generation advanced manufacturing technologies, such as 3D printing, aerosol jet direct write, roll-to-roll, fiber weaving, and intense pulse light curing.  As such, our site addresses the challenges associated with manufacturing over a wide variety of lengthscales, from the nano-scale, to the micro-scale, to the meso-scale, up to the macro-scale. Thus, our NNCI site's expertise is multiscale manufacturing as illustrated in Figure 2.  Such manufacturing diversity and integration across various lengthscales are critical to the technological health of the United States, as it supports research in a wide assortment of important application spaces, including wearable technologies, micro-fluidics, next-generation robotics, flexible electronics and optics, energy conservation and harvesting, extreme environmental conditions, and novel sensing. The KY Multiscale initiative helps maintain our nation's technologically competitiveness on a global landscape.  KY Multiscale is the primary NNCI site addressing the needs and challenges associated with the inevitable convergence of nanotechnology and additive manufacturing.  Through the KY Multiscale initiative, we offer many programs of tremendous value to our national users from industry, government and academia.  The following is a list of the programs offered by KY Multiscale along with outcomes: 1) open access by industry, government, and academia to a broad set of over 200 state-of-the-art nanotechnology and additive manufacturing tools, 2) a diverse set of nearly 500 users from all across the nation which has grown dramatically since the inception of the KY Multiscale initiative, 3) a professional staff to train those users, provide technical advice, and maintain the expensive and complex toolset, 4) a comprehensive website which includes training videos, an event calendar, testimonials,  list of collaborators, on-line portal for reserving tool time, seminar series, seed program information, a video gallery, job opportunities, valuable data usage reports, and a data base of all our tools, services, and programs, 5) a popular monthly newsletter that reaches over 8,000  recipients from all across the United States, 6) an interdisciplinary Seed Program to support and  encourage non-traditional users from all disciplines, 7) various in-person and virtual seminars/webinars appropriate for all levels, 8) an exciting Annual Nano+AM Symposium which  brings together over 200 researchers from the micro/nanotechnology and additive manufacturing communities (see Figure 3), 9) a popular 10-week summer research experience that draws undergraduate from all around the United States and trains them in the fields of micro/nanotechnology and additive manufacturing (see Figure 4), 10) an exciting education and outreach program that reaches over 5,000 K-12 students with collaborations from our state's science museum and other educational entities in the Commonwealth of Kentucky, 11) custom equipment for fabricating at the intersection of the micro/nano and the meso/macro lengthscales (see Figure 5), 12) exciting, ground-breaking research involving nanotechnology and additive manufacturing that addresses many of our nation's challenges in the areas of healthcare, defense, energy, the environment, advanced manufacturing, communication, and food security (see Figure 6), and finally 13) service as a national center of excellence for current and next generation 2D/2.5D/3D advanced manufacturing across a wide range of lengthscales.

 


Last Modified: 12/24/2021
Modified by: Kevin M Walsh
